###5. 

The general syntax for linear regression in R is:
model_name <- lm(y_variable ~ x_variable, data = df_name)

So, if I have a data frame called â€˜salmonâ€™ containing variables â€˜yearâ€™ and â€˜salmon_fresh,â€™ I would use: salmon_model <- lm(salmon_fresh ~ year, data = salmon)

```{r}
salmon_final_graph <- ggplot(salmon, aes(x = year, y = salmon_fresh)) +
geom_point() +
geom_smooth(method = lm, se = TRUE, size = 0.5, color = "gray20") +
theme_bw() +

labs(x = "Year", y = "U.S. Annual Fresh Salmon Imports\n(1,000 pounds)")

salmon_final_graph
```
###9.
Letâ€™s say we want to use our model to make predictions for U.S. fresh salmon imports in years 2022, 2024, 2026 and 2028.
```{r}
#  Option 2 (recommended): Create a data frame containing the â€˜new valuesâ€™ that you want to make predictions for, feed that into the predict() function

new_years <- data.frame(year = c(2022, 2024, 2026, 2028))

new_years

# Then feed that data frame into the predict() function, letting it know which model to use to make predictions for the new values.Include interval = â€œconfidenceâ€ to also report the lower and upper bounds of the 95% CI for model fit at each year.

future_predict <- predict(salmon_lr, newdata = new_years, interval = "confidence")

future_predict

# Bind the prediction outcomes (those are the values in column â€˜fitâ€™) with the â€˜new_yearsâ€™ data to actually create a useful table of predicted imports and upper and lower CI:

predictions <- data.frame(new_years, future_predict)

predictions
```

Use the cor.test() function to find Pearsonâ€™s r for the linear relationship described between year and salmon imports.

Generally, if youâ€™re trying to explore the correlation between variable_1 and variable_2 in data frame â€˜dfâ€™, the function syntax is as follows:

